title: Programming in Basic R
text:
1.1 Create the blood pressure vector before treatment. Suppose we have data from a medical experiment on blood pressure. We have the following pre-treatment values for subjects 1 through 20:

pre_bp <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
pre_bp

 [1] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 127 122 127 135 133 128 147 138 140
[20] 132


Create the blood pressure vector after treatment. after treatment, the subject were measure again (subject 1 to 20 match)

post_bp <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)
post_bp

 [1] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 132 146 120 114 121 120 128 120 133
[20] 115


1.2 Assign names to the vector elements

names(pre_bp) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
names(post_bp) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep="_")

names(post_bp)

 [1] "Subject_1"  "Subject_2"  "Subject_3"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_5" 
 [6] "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8"  "Subject_9"  "Subject_10"
[11] "Subject_11" "Subject_12" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[16] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"


1.3 Calculate the change in blood pressure for each patient by subtracting post-treatment measurements from pre-treatment measurements. Recall that R does math element-wise! Save this calculation as a new object in R (also a vector).

diff_bp <- pre_bp - post_bp
diff_bp

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
        -7          6        -10          4          0         10          9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
         3          8         10         -5        -24          7         21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
        12          8         19         18          7         17 

typeof(diff_bp)

[1] "double"


1.4 Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure across all patients Using mean() function.

avg_decrease <- mean(diff_bp)
avg_decrease

[1] 5.65


1.5 Determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment (a positive change). Use the which() function to just return the indices (and names) associated with this type of change.

positive_change_indices <- which(diff_bp > 0)
positive_change_indices

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 

# Note we can also use following code to just output the names
#positive_change_names <- names(diff_bp)[positive_change_indices]
#positive_change_names

1.6 Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change. (Note that you don’t need the which() function here. A Boolean used as an indexing vector returns only indices were a TRUE occurred.)

positive_changes <- diff_bp[diff_bp > 0]
positive_changes

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 


1.7 Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those with a positive change

avg_positive_decrease <- mean(positive_changes)

avg_positive_decrease

[1] 10.6

title: Programming in Basic R
text:
1.1 Create the blood pressure vector before treatment. Suppose we have data from a medical experiment on blood pressure. We have the following pre-treatment values for subjects 1 through 20:

pre_bp <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
pre_bp

 [1] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 127 122 127 135 133 128 147 138 140
[20] 132


Create the blood pressure vector after treatment. after treatment, the subject were measure again (subject 1 to 20 match)

post_bp <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)
post_bp

 [1] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 132 146 120 114 121 120 128 120 133
[20] 115


1.2 Assign names to the vector elements

names(pre_bp) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
names(post_bp) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep="_")

names(post_bp)

 [1] "Subject_1"  "Subject_2"  "Subject_3"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_5" 
 [6] "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8"  "Subject_9"  "Subject_10"
[11] "Subject_11" "Subject_12" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[16] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"


1.3 Calculate the change in blood pressure for each patient by subtracting post-treatment measurements from pre-treatment measurements. Recall that R does math element-wise! Save this calculation as a new object in R (also a vector).

diff_bp <- pre_bp - post_bp
diff_bp

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
        -7          6        -10          4          0         10          9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
         3          8         10         -5        -24          7         21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
        12          8         19         18          7         17 

typeof(diff_bp)

[1] "double"


1.4 Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure across all patients Using mean() function.

avg_decrease <- mean(diff_bp)
avg_decrease

[1] 5.65


1.5 Determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment (a positive change). Use the which() function to just return the indices (and names) associated with this type of change.

positive_change_indices <- which(diff_bp > 0)
positive_change_indices

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 

# Note we can also use following code to just output the names
#positive_change_names <- names(diff_bp)[positive_change_indices]
#positive_change_names

1.6 Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change. (Note that you don’t need the which() function here. A Boolean used as an indexing vector returns only indices were a TRUE occurred.)

positive_changes <- diff_bp[diff_bp > 0]
positive_changes

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 


1.7 Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those with a positive change

avg_positive_decrease <- mean(positive_changes)

avg_positive_decrease

[1] 10.6

title: Programming in Basic R
text:
Task 2: Basic Data Frame practice
Continue the previous example.
2.1 Create a data frame object with four columns corresponding to your data above in Task 1: patient, pre_bp, post_bp, and diff_bp

bp_data <- data.frame(
  patient = paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_"),
  pre_bp = pre_bp,
  post_bp = post_bp,
  diff_bp = diff_bp
)

str(bp_data)

'data.frame':   20 obs. of  4 variables:
 $ patient: chr  "Subject_1" "Subject_2" "Subject_3" "Subject_4" ...
 $ pre_bp : num  120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 ...
 $ post_bp: num  127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 ...
 $ diff_bp: num  -7 6 -10 4 0 10 9 3 8 10 ...


2.2 Return only rows of the data frame where the diff_bp column is negative. (Use [ or learn about the subset() function if you’d like. If you use [, don’t reference the original vector from the first part, access the column of the data frame to make your comparison with 0.)

#[bp_data$diff_bp] will access the column diff_bp from data frame bp_data

negative_changes <- bp_data[bp_data$diff_bp < 0, ]
negative_changes

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24


2.3 Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the post_bp is less than 120 and FALSE if it is not. Similar to the previous question, don’t reference the original vector from task 1, access the column of the data frame to make your comparison. Recall you can use $ to access a column. If you reference a column that doesn’t exist and save a vector (of appropriate length in it), that vector becomes a column of your data frame! Use this way of creating the new column.

#Here new column (below_120bp) is created in the data frame bp_data
bp_data$below_120bp <- ifelse(bp_data$post_bp < 120, TRUE, FALSE)
bp_data

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp below_120bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7       FALSE
Subject_2   Subject_2    151     145       6       FALSE
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10       FALSE
Subject_4   Subject_4    126     122       4       FALSE
Subject_5   Subject_5    115     115       0        TRUE
Subject_6   Subject_6    132     122      10       FALSE
Subject_7   Subject_7    132     123       9       FALSE
Subject_8   Subject_8    129     126       3       FALSE
Subject_9   Subject_9    134     126       8       FALSE
Subject_10 Subject_10    139     129      10       FALSE
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5       FALSE
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24       FALSE
Subject_13 Subject_13    127     120       7       FALSE
Subject_14 Subject_14    135     114      21        TRUE
Subject_15 Subject_15    133     121      12       FALSE
Subject_16 Subject_16    128     120       8       FALSE
Subject_17 Subject_17    147     128      19       FALSE
Subject_18 Subject_18    138     120      18       FALSE
Subject_19 Subject_19    140     133       7       FALSE
Subject_20 Subject_20    132     115      17        TRUE


2.4 Print the data set

knitr::kable(bp_data)

pre_bp

diff_bp

title: Programming in Basic R
text:
Task 3: List Practice
Continue the previous example. Suppose we now also have data from another experiment where the ‘treatment’ was actually a placebo. We have the following pre-treatment values for subjects 1 through 10 (different set of subjects): • 138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130 after treatment, the subjects were measured again (subjects 1 through 10 match) • 105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124
3.1: Create a new data frame with this data in it that is similar to the data frame from task 2 (including the new column of TRUE/FALSE values).

# Pre-treatment BP values
pre_bp_placebo <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)

# Post-treatment BP values
post_bp_placebo <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)

#Create a new data frame with this data in it that is similar to the data frame from task 2 (including the new column of TRUE/FALSE values).

placebo_df <- data.frame(
  patient = 1:10,
  pre_bp_placebo = pre_bp_placebo,
  post_bp_placebo = post_bp_placebo,
  diff_bp = pre_bp_placebo - post_bp_placebo,
  below_120 = ifelse(post_bp < 120, TRUE, FALSE)
)
placebo_df

           patient pre_bp_placebo post_bp_placebo diff_bp below_120
Subject_1        1            138             105      33     FALSE
Subject_2        2            135             136      -1     FALSE
Subject_3        3            147             123      24     FALSE
Subject_4        4            117             130     -13     FALSE
Subject_5        5            152             134      18      TRUE
Subject_6        6            134             143      -9     FALSE
Subject_7        7            114             135     -21     FALSE
Subject_8        8            121             139     -18     FALSE
Subject_9        9            131             120      11     FALSE
Subject_10      10            130             124       6     FALSE
Subject_11       1            138             105      33     FALSE
Subject_12       2            135             136      -1     FALSE
Subject_13       3            147             123      24     FALSE
Subject_14       4            117             130     -13      TRUE
Subject_15       5            152             134      18     FALSE
Subject_16       6            134             143      -9     FALSE
Subject_17       7            114             135     -21     FALSE
Subject_18       8            121             139     -18     FALSE
Subject_19       9            131             120      11     FALSE
Subject_20      10            130             124       6      TRUE


3.2: Now create and store a list with two elements: • 1nd element named treatment and contains the first data frame you created. • 2nd element named placebo and contains the second data frame you created.

experiment_list <- list(
  treatment = bp_data,
  placebo = placebo_df
)

typeof(experiment_list)

[1] "list"

print(experiment_list)

$treatment
              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp below_120bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7       FALSE
Subject_2   Subject_2    151     145       6       FALSE
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10       FALSE
Subject_4   Subject_4    126     122       4       FALSE
Subject_5   Subject_5    115     115       0        TRUE
Subject_6   Subject_6    132     122      10       FALSE
Subject_7   Subject_7    132     123       9       FALSE
Subject_8   Subject_8    129     126       3       FALSE
Subject_9   Subject_9    134     126       8       FALSE
Subject_10 Subject_10    139     129      10       FALSE
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5       FALSE
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24       FALSE
Subject_13 Subject_13    127     120       7       FALSE
Subject_14 Subject_14    135     114      21        TRUE
Subject_15 Subject_15    133     121      12       FALSE
Subject_16 Subject_16    128     120       8       FALSE
Subject_17 Subject_17    147     128      19       FALSE
Subject_18 Subject_18    138     120      18       FALSE
Subject_19 Subject_19    140     133       7       FALSE
Subject_20 Subject_20    132     115      17        TRUE

$placebo
           patient pre_bp_placebo post_bp_placebo diff_bp below_120
Subject_1        1            138             105      33     FALSE
Subject_2        2            135             136      -1     FALSE
Subject_3        3            147             123      24     FALSE
Subject_4        4            117             130     -13     FALSE
Subject_5        5            152             134      18      TRUE
Subject_6        6            134             143      -9     FALSE
Subject_7        7            114             135     -21     FALSE
Subject_8        8            121             139     -18     FALSE
Subject_9        9            131             120      11     FALSE
Subject_10      10            130             124       6     FALSE
Subject_11       1            138             105      33     FALSE
Subject_12       2            135             136      -1     FALSE
Subject_13       3            147             123      24     FALSE
Subject_14       4            117             130     -13      TRUE
Subject_15       5            152             134      18     FALSE
Subject_16       6            134             143      -9     FALSE
Subject_17       7            114             135     -21     FALSE
Subject_18       8            121             139     -18     FALSE
Subject_19       9            131             120      11     FALSE
Subject_20      10            130             124       6      TRUE


3.3: Access the first list element using three different types of syntax

# Method 1: Using the $ operator
treatment_df_1 <- experiment_list$treatment

# Method 2: Using double square brackets
treatment_df_2 <- experiment_list[[1]]

# Method 3: Using single square brackets (returns a list)
treatment_list <- experiment_list["treatment"]
treatment_df_3 <- treatment_list$treatment

print(treatment_df_1)

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp below_120bp

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp below_120bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7       FALSE
Subject_2   Subject_2    151     145       6       FALSE

3.4: Use your list from question 2. In one line of code, access the pre_bp column of the placebo data frame.

experiment_list[[2]]$pre_bp_placebo

 [1] 138 135 147 117 152 134 114 121 131 130 138 135 147 117 152 134 114 121 131
[20] 130
